= Grub-image =


=== Install Dependencies: ===
Ensure you have the necessary tools installed. On a Debian-based system, you can use:
``
sudo apt-get install grub-pc grub-image xorriso
``
=== Create a GRUB Image: ===
Run the following command to create a GRUB image:
``
grub-image --grub-setup=/bin/true
``
This will generate a file named grub.img.

=== Mount the partition containing your ISOs. ===
For example:
``
sudo mount /dev/sdX1 /mnt/iso_partition
``
=== Copy ISOs to the GRUB Image: ===
Copy the contents of the ISOs to the GRUB image:
``
sudo cp -r /mnt/iso_partition/* /mnt/grub_partition/boot
``
=== Install GRUB to the Image: ===

``sudo grub-install --no-floppy --force --modules="normal part_msdos ext2 iso9660 biosdisk" --boot-directory=/mnt/grub_partition/boot /dev/sdX
``
Replace /dev/sdX with the correct device for your GRUB partition.

=== Configure GRUB: ===
Create a grub.cfg file in the /mnt/grub_partition/boot/grub/ directory with the following content:
``
set timeout=10
set default=0

menuentry "ISO 1" {
    set isofile="/boot/your_iso_file1.iso"
    loopback loop $isofile
    linux (loop)/casper/vmlinuz boot=casper iso-scan/filename=$isofile splash --
    initrd (loop)/casper/initrd.lz
}

menuentry "ISO 2" {
    set isofile="/boot/your_iso_file2.iso"
    loopback loop $isofile
    linux (loop)/casper/vmlinuz boot=casper iso-scan/filename=$isofile splash --
    initrd (loop)/casper/initrd.lz
}
``
# Add more entries for each ISO
Update the entries with the correct paths to your ISO files.

=== Unmount Partitions: ===
Unmount the partitions:
``
sudo umount /mnt/iso_partition
``
Now, you can use grub.img to boot multiple ISOs from GRUB.
